messages.content:
Hello,
Is it possible to call another contract method from a contract?
Usecase would be Proxy Contract.

yes https://docs.minaprotocol.com/zkapps/o1js/smart-contracts#composing-zkapps

what would be the use case of proxy contract?

embeds.title: Mina Documentation
embeds.description: Website for documentation about Mina Protocol

messages.content:
For upgradeability and versioning of the contract
In the Proxy Contract the Owner is allowed to change the destination Contract address. With this you can Upgrade contracts for example to update (more Features, fixing etc)
Or can you always edit the Contract itself? I only Developed on Ethereum and there is a Proxy needed.

There is a `setVerificationKey` permission for upgradeability https://docs.minaprotocol.com/zkapps/o1js/permissions. I recommend going through the documentation, the smart contracts model on Mina is quite different from evm.
Ah
So when i deploy it with the Same keys its updating itself?
You can change the verification key to change the logic of the smart contract.
Is there an Tutorial on how to update the smart Contract with These verification keys?
yes on the page that I've linked https://docs.minaprotocol.com/zkapps/o1js/permissions#example-upgradeable-with-a-proof

embeds.title: Mina Documentation
embeds.description: Website for documentation about Mina Protocol

messages.content: Hello, i don't see how is this happening, what i saw was not to change the contract/circuit logic. Do you know any codebase for example of changing the SC ( adding/removing methods etc. and not only changing permissions) ?
You can check the example at https://github.com/zkcloudworker/zkcloudworker-tests/blob/main/tests/vk.test.ts

Okay - what i see here is changing verification keys of zkappps with same public keys. But do they transform to each other? For example, does zkapp1 becomes zkapp2 (meaning that, new instance will have 2 fields and a new method) after changing verification key? 

If so, would it be if public keys of zkapps were not same? 

My aim is to see if Mina zkApps necessarily needs a proxy contract as in Ethereum or not.

Thank you so much!
Yes if you change the vk of a deployed contract, it "becomes" the new contract.
@DFST brilliant script!  Mind if I copy that and put it in the docs?
Sure, it is public, you can use it. It is just better to use it on devnet as you will be able to see all txs in explorer

Even though it feels so controversial that it happens, it is so awesome!

So in that case, the proxy contract approach for 'upgradable contracts'   in ethereum is not needed in Mina!

Sure, just the question is what permissions you should set to the verification key upgrade process and who will control the private key that allows to upgrade. Probably multisig is the best answer for the future.
I added a new article about upgradability here: https://docs.minaprotocol.com/zkapps/writing-a-zkapp/feature-overview/upgradability

I've created a more advanced example of upgradability that can be used in cases when the protocol version does not change, but o1js breaks verification keys (as in o1js 2.0.0, for example)
https://github.com/dfstio/nft-standard-draft/blob/master-nft/tests/vk-upgrade.test.ts
DFST sir is a literal gangsta :coolface:

@here
I have prepared end-to-end example of upgrading the contract from o1js v1 to o1js v2, applicable also to the future upgrades:
https://github.com/dfstio/upgrade-example

This repo illustrates the process of upgrading the verification key of the sample SmartContract from the verification key generated by o1js 1.9.1 to the verification key generated by o1js 2.1.0 using the private voting mechanism.
This is a monorepo with two packages (v1 and v2). Both packages use the same SmartContract but different versions of o1js. Any contract can be used as a sample contract, and many verification keys can be included in the database with one tx and one voting process.

Please also check the blog post by @Florian on o1js v2:
https://www.o1labs.org/blog/introducing-o1js-v2

Hi @DFST , Could you clarify if this topic is solely focused on upgrading the contract code from O1js 1.9.1 to O1js 2.1.0, or does it also provide a solution for upgrading the contract while preserving the existing address and transaction history?
You can also use this example to upgrade the contract at any time. The different o1js versions were chosen as it is a more complicated case when the new o1js version breaks the verification keys.
Thanks, So the main key for upgradability is still the verification keys, Right ?
Yes, correct
